label: Full-Stack Development
description: Become a full-stack web developer using the 2 most popular technologies in the world: Javascript, React and Python

weeks.label: Week 1: How does the web work?
weeks.summary: Understanding HTTP, the browser, the Client-Server model, creating your first HTML, The head & body HTML, tables.

days.label: Day 1
days.description: Welcome to web development: At the beginning there was only HTML, years later CSS appeared, and that's how the web 1.0 came to life
days.instructions: You have 15 minutes to explain how HTTP works by sending-receiving text between servers & clients, and how the browsers interpret that text as HTML, CSS or JS and then start coding. Start the postcard HTML on the screen and students should finishe it. Use float layout pursposes instead of display inline-block.
days.homework: The students must finish the Postcard on their own (there is a video-tutorial)

days.label: Day 2
days.description: Websites became popular and CSS evolved to enable amazing layouts with boxes and also a rich set of CSS Selectors
days.instructions: Connecting CSS & HTML: Finish the postcard and start the Instagram Feed. Review all the key concepts with your students.
days.homework: Students must finish the Instagram & the Postcard.
key-concepts: Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity)

days.label: Day 3
days.description: Bootstrap arrived to profesionalize websites, removing 99% of the layout pain. Everything is a component from now on.
days.instructions: Explain bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain. Everything is a component from now own.
key-concepts: Workflow: Identify the components, Copy&Paste them and finally customize them
Helper/Utility Classes that come with Bootstrap

days.label: Weekend
days.description: And God created the coding weekends - the perfect place to practice, share and collaborate with your classmates.
days.instructions: Students must finish all pending projects!

weeks.label: Week 2: The Terminal & GIT
weeks.summary: Time to start having a professional workflow

days.label: Day 4
days.description: A text editor and the console - that's all you need to be a great coder. Time to master the second one.
days.teacher_instructions: Teach the command line to your students, use the CMD challenge to make it very fun! Start with a small explanation about the importance of the CMD and then explain each command after its respective challenge is completed.
days.homework: At the end of the class, present the students with the GIT project & please ask each student to start coding its corresponding part of the website.

days.label: Day 5
days.description: The CMD Line has millions of tools, it's time to learn the first ones: GIT & Github - together they make collaboration amazing!
days.instructions: Time to explain and practice with GIT in detail, create a repository for your Landing Page GIT project and make them clone it and upload their piece of the project. Review the key concepts.
days.homework: At the end of the class, present the students with the GIT project & please ask each student to start coding its corresponding part of the Landing Page. Suggested parts: navbar, jumbotron, 2 parts description, product showcase, marketing banner, contact us, footer

days.label: Day 6
days.teacher_instructions: Finish pending replits (all css and html related), upload student projects into their github accounts and finish the Student External Profile
days.description: Your entire time at the academy can de summarized into one landing page: The Student External Profile. It is time to start building it.
key-concepts: What is the Student External Profile

days.label: Weekend
days.description: It has been two crazy weeks, thank God we have another coding weekend to keep up and practice.
days.instructions: Students must finish HTML, CSS3, Layout, Bootstrap, GIT and deliver all the projects through the online platform.

weeks.label: Week 3: First coding skills
weeks.summary: Learn to loop, work with arrays, if..else and functions. Create algorithms.

days.label: Day 7
days.description: HTML & CSS are great, but the world needed interactive pages (not just beautiful text documents). JavaScript comes to help us generate HTML & CSS based commands after the initial text document has already loaded.  JavaScript will also re-write the website live, based on the user's activity.
days.instructions: First take time to do the group activity and explain coding concepts (read the full instrucitons), then start the excuse generator is a great way to explain how JavaScript and HTML/CSS can play together. Do it with the students as you explain all the programming Key Concepts. Use the VanillaJS boilerplate, that way students will start getting used to it
days.homework: Students need to finish the Excuse Generator, make the replits about JavaScript and complete the layout for the Random Card Generator

days.label: Day 8
days.instructions: Finish conditional profile card and all previous replits. Ask students to gather and create a flow chart on the whiteboard with the decision process behind building the html for the profile card project.
days.description: What we call "thinking" it's basically the process of making decitions based on some information (variables) that we have available. You can replicate the same behavior in a computer by using conditionals and logical operations.
days.homework: Finish the profile card and replits to date
key-concepts: Some times else is not needed
Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.

days.label: Day 9
days.instructions: Take 15 min for answers, 15 min to explain arrays and then present the Domain Name Generator to the students and ask them to strategize on the white board, before starting to code reinforce the ONLOAD function as the beginning of your application, start using the breathecode-cli and vanilla-js
days.description: Arrays are the only way to have a list of things in programming, and they are challenging because develoeprs need to master the art of getting or setting values from arrays using loops
days.homework: Finish the domain name generator and all the pending replits
key-concepts: Use querySelector() to select DOM Elements just like you do with CSS
Add/Remove CSS Classes to DOM elements
Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Saturdays are a great oportunity to work all day on your coding skills with extra lessons without extra charges. You will only sacrifice 14 Saturdays and your life will change forever.
days.instructions: During the weekend, students must finish all the replits

weeks.label: Week 4: Mastering Vanilla JS
weeks.warning: Students need to be comfortable looping already

days.label: Day 10
days.description: You have a lot of things to cach up on, finish and deliver the replit exercises and projects.
days.instructions: Help students finish the replit exercises and projects.
days.project: Work on the replits and projects
days.homework: Finished Replits and Projects

days.label: Day 11
days.instructions: Do the Random Card but focusing a lot on the workflow (how to plan and begin coding), reinforce the ONLOAD and PRE-LOAD main events and how to change CSS with JS, make students do the 'Map Of Events' to strategize, start using the breathecode-cli and vanilla-js
days.description: Ok but how do we use JavaScript to build websites? You have to interact with the DOM whenever an event occurs
days.homework: Finish the Random Card and pending replits, start DOM & EVENTS replits
key-concepts: Use querySelector() to select DOM Elements just like you do with CSS
Add/Remove CSS Classes to DOM elements
Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.

days.label: Day 12
days.description: You have a lot of things to cach up on, finish and deliver the replit exercises and projects. Make sure to review the last replit of events (todo list).
days.instructions: Help students finish the replit exercises and projects. Make sure to review the last replit of events (todo list). IMPORANT: This next coding weekend will be the last before getting into react, encourage students to attend.
days.project: Work on the replits and projects
days.homework: Finished Replits and Projects

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Every student, partner, teacher and alumni is invited to the academy on Saturdays, it is an oportunity to network and get some inspiration!
days.teacher_instructions: Finish the all pending projects, replits and the Project User Stories
days.homework: Finish all pending assignments and also your first draft of the project user stories

weeks.label: Week 5: React JS
weeks.summary: Time to start working on the project using Agile Methodologies

days.label: Day 13
days.instructions: It's the first time students will be using objects, explain the concept. Make students create their first react components and explain the use of JSX. Explain the difference between Functional components and or class components and the render function. Landing page project should be a code along at start, then groups at end.
days.description: But working with the DOM can get tricky and it's resource consuming, for that and many other reasons libraries like React.js got popular in the last couple of years. The let you create HTML and CSS using JS in a very intuitive way.
days.homework: Students must finish the landing page with react for the next class

lessons.title: Importing and Exporting from other JS files

replits.title: Using React.js as a Rendering Engine

key-concepts: You can create your own tags
Create a Component like a Class
Create a Component like a Function

days.label: Day 14
days.description: Its the first time you've heard or learn about react, we have given you a lot of exercises to practice. Please practice like crazy with all of them. Ask questions.
days.instructions: Students have now a lot of homework: The React Replits, Traffic Light, Counter and the Landing page. Work with students to help them complete the developments.
days.project: Work on the replits and projects
days.homework: Finished Replits and Projects

days.label: Day 15
days.instructions: Review landing page. React as rendering engine: Students need to understand that now they can finally create their own HTML tags (React Components) and how to use the State and the Props. Have the class discuss the strategy for todo-list
days.description: Finally we can create our own HTML tags and re-use them on several projects and views. The key to understand a component is understanding Props and The State. Please continue working on the Todo-List Application.
key-concepts: Using const, map, filter and concat to prevent state mutation
days.homework: Students must finish the TodoList being able to add & delete tasks.

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Now that you are working on the final project, it is the best time to meet with your partner to work on the weekends
days.instructions: Student Projects Views must be finished by next class

weeks.label: Week 6: React Router & Layout
weeks.summary: Real life frontend apps using React Router and Context

days.label: Day 16
days.teacher_instructions: Time to start the Final project! Let's give the students a break and dive into User Stories and the SCRUM methodology. Students must pick their projects & partner, and start building the user stories on Trello.com, create the board with them.
days.description: Force students to finish all that's due. Time to start the Final project! Lets review how software is built today, you'll learn and follow the same methods used by the top tech companies in the world.

project.title: Final Project User Stories and Wireframes

key-concepts: What is a Kanban board and how does it work
How to use Github's kanban automated board
Adding one issue per user story
Writting stories int he users point of view
days.homework: Students must finish the user stories by next class, remember that the student projects must meet certain conditions to be accepted.

days.label: Day 17
days.instructions: Students that have not finished the replits cannot enter the class and will practice separated from the main group. Explain the logic behind React Router, and the things to remember. React Router + React: How to create components that behave like Views (layouts), match show them when a particualr URL is in place
days.description: But some React components will never be reused, they behave more like pages or layouts. We will call those components: 'Views'... React will help us connect them together to create our main website navigation
key-concepts: Using the React Debugging Chrome Plugin
Debugging code with the Chrome Source Tab
days.homework: Sit with every project team and discuss how to split the code into Views vs Components, students must finish their project home layout by next class

days.label: Day 18
days.instructions: Demonstrate component lifecycle methods: getDerivedStateFromProps, DidMount and willUnmount.
days.description: MVC (Model-View-Controller) is one of the most popular coding design patterns, its main goal is to split the business data from the component state. Now your project will have Views, Actions (the controller) and a centralized Store (the model)
days.homework: Students must create a contact management app using React Router, Context & Component lifecycle methods
key-concepts: Updating the store from within the actions

weeks.warning: The students should keep working on their final project's documentation

weeks.label: Week 7: Practice Week!
weeks.summary: Work on the project and catch up with all the assignments

days.label: Day 19
days.description: How to make a formal frontend web app using navigation (React Router)
days.instructions: Force students to finish all that's due, students that have not finished the replits cannot enter the class and will remain separated from the big group. Explain the logic behind React Router, and the things to remember
days.homework: Students must deliver the first views of their projects

days.label: Day 20
days.instructions: Force students to finish all that's due, students that have not finished the replits cannot enter the class and will remain separated from the big group. Explain the logic behind React Router, and the things to remember
days.description: How to make a formal frontend web app using navigation (React Router)
days.homework: Students (in groups) must create a 4 page website (Home, Blog, Product, Checkout-Cart) using React Router

days.label: Day 21
days.description: Practice everything you've learned
days.homework: Students must deliver all previous assignments

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Practice everything you've learned

weeks.label: Week 8: fetch(HTTP-JSON)
weeks.summary: Use the JavaScript Fetch native object to do API Requests and Receive the JSON Responses

days.label: Day 22
days.instructions: Intro to HTTP: Re-Explain HTTP Requests but now using GET, POST, PUT & DELETE. Introduce JSON instead of HTML as the main communication format. Serialize and Unserialize.
days.description: When your real application is almost ready, it's time to integrate with a real database. That will enable it to work with real information: Create, Update, Delete and get real data. We do HTTP Requests for that.

project.title: Use the Contact Manage API to save, delete and update the contacts

key-concepts: How to use POSTMan, set environment variables and use collections
JSON is a JavaScript object but as TEXT
The goal is to send/receive everything as JSON Serialize>Send>Unserialize
What is serialization and how to do it (Parsing)
Why use several request types (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)?
Explain the 3 main content-types: Form, URL-Encoded, Raw (With JSON)
days.homework: Using POSTman, and then using React, students must consume the API to Save, Delete and Update Contacts.

days.label: Day 23
days.instructions: Finish the Contact Managment API integration, focus on Debugging procedures and start the introduction to Python
days.description: Make sure to finish the contact management project
days.homework: Students must finish the Contact Management API Integration

days.label: Day 24
days.instructions: One last day to finish the Contact Managment Application with your students, review all the Context, React, Components and HTTP Ajax concepts and best practices
days.description: Make sure to finish the contact management project
days.homework: Students must finish the Contact Management Application

days.label: Weekend
days.description: And here we go again, perfect saturday to work on the project!
days.instructions: As homework students must review the Lessons and Videos about Python, Django-Rest

weeks.label: Week 9: Create your own API
weeks.summary: Creating an API use Python, Django & Rest

days.label: Day 25
days.instructions: First, run a simple Python script in the shell, explain the benefits and capabilities that it brings in the back-end. Then, install Django using the boilerplate and create one simple endpoint with a very simple model (no relations)
days.description: Welcome to the back-end! The back-end side has almost no limitations, you have access to the entire computer, printers or anything you need. Your life as a back-end developer will start by doing API's because it is the most needed skill in the market. We really hope you like it as much as we do!
key-concepts: Python has access to the Entire Machine
days.homework: Students must create the required models for the Contact Management Application

days.label: Day 26
days.instructions: Practice the Django-Rest MVC Workflow to create new endpoints, focus on how the Django ORM works and how to create relationships
days.description: The most frequent backend operation is writing in a database and there are two main ways of doing so: 'Using SQL' or 'not using SQL', let's start by reviewing how SQL works and why it's so influential in the database world
days.homework: Stutents create all the models of the contact management API and continue building the endpoints

days.label: Day 27
days.instructions: Continue doing the endpoints with your students
days.description: Finish the Contact Management API and it's time to start working on your project API

days.label: Weekend
days.instructions: From now on repetition is key, start every class reviewing the development workflow, help students finish their project and motivate them until the end!
days.description: We know you are really overwhelmed by the incredible amount of information, the next few weeks are about practice, practice, and practice! It's is time to become a master in software development

weeks.label: Week 12: Keep it up
weeks.summary: Working on the Final Project and Resum√©

days.label: Day 34
days.instructions: Student should be working on the final projects, continue working with them. Also, during this class, pelase take 20 minutes to make students update their Student Profile Projects
days.description: You are in the middle of the final project development, but please take some time to review your Student Public Profile and update it
days.homework: Student will continue working on their final project and also write their projects description, reame file, etc.

days.label: Weekend
days.instructions: From now on repetition is key, start every class reviewing the development workflow, help students finish their project and motivate them until the end!
days.description: Weekds are open to students as always, keep it up with your Final Project!

weeks.label: Week 16
weeks.summary: Last tweeks to the project and building of the final presentation

days.label: Day 46
days.instructions: Help students start their presentation, give them tips and setup a rehersal date to work with them on their presentation
days.description: Did you notice that 16 weeks had passed? Times passes fast when you are having fun, not it's time to work on the final project presentation

project.title: Work on the Final Project Presentation

key-concepts: Making sure your dummy data looks great
How to focus on the strengths
days.homework: Create your project presentation

days.label: Day 47
days.instructions: Create a 'rehersal day' and let the students present the project to their classmates
days.description: A great way of rehearsing is by presenting the final project to your classmates

days.label: Pitch Day
days.instructions: Answer any question your students may have
days.description: You have worked a lot during these weeks, it's time to present the final project and enjoy with your family and friends!
